Content: Definitely a far cry from Basecamp's intuitive design.  Although, this may evolve into something worthwhile in it's own respect, as ActiveState's Komodo Edit is my editor of choice: it's fast, free, extensible and open source.  In it's current state 'ActiveState Workspace' doesn't seem like much, but I'm interested to see how it evolves.

Author: silentbicycle
Content:
> I just feel kind of annoyed that the replies seem to suggest I was stupid in not mentioning the hotspot idea.

I didn't mean anything personal, and I don't read any of the other comments that way.

The other comments may have just been voted up by people who also like Lua or Mercurial, or something. I thought it was worth noting that Lua was explicitly designed for that style of development. (Lua's also my favorite language.)

Author: kscaldef

Author: stcredzero
Content: What about beamed power?  With the power of modern electric motors, freed from the burden of carrying the batteries or fuel, there would be a tremendous gain in efficiency.

Author: xsmasher
Content:
When you're doing what you love, you'll have fun and you'll succeed.

The first time I heard "You have to find your bliss," it sounded like new-age claptrap to me. It took time to sink in - the way I understand it now is that someone who is dedicated to an idea will put in his blood, sweat, and tears; and they'll probably have a great time to boot. That extra dedication will lead to success, not in a mystical laws-of-attraction way, but in a concrete, practice-makes perfect way.

Author: lyime
Content: They have around 25m users according to TC. that makes it about $28 per user. Which is alright, I have seen higher numbers per user.

Author: potatolicious
Content:
I highly doubt this is real - and if it were I'd be extremely disappointed in Apple. $700M is better invested in a lot of technology that will get them real gains, as opposed to buying a service that is neither profitable nor in possession of any technology that can't be replicated in-house for cheaper.

So at best they're buying the brand - which is still nothing near household, and I would argue worth a lot less than the quoted price tag.

Author: kyro
Content:
"get over it."

Why is this getting voted up? The guy's not sobbing and there's no harm in using hyperbole.

Dustin is a very talented designer, and I'm sure he runs into this sort of stuff all the time through the work he does, so it makes sense that these details are more visible and have a greater effect on him than they would with any normal viewer.

Author: edd
Content:
A UK newspaper website?

Author: Radix
Content: Notice that 'most' refers to 'popular' not 'advanced'.  So, the point I believe you were making has nothing to stand against.  MySQL is very popular and is also advanced.

Author: mikedouglas
Content:
There is a difference between applying your core competencies to different markets, and just expanding. Apple has been good at limiting their growth to the former. When they do expand into unfamiliar areas (like with iTunes), they make sure they contribute to the bottom line (through increased iPod/iPhone sales).

There are already good Twitter applications for both the Mac and the iPhone. Apple gains nothing, and loses $700 million.

I've been an ER nurse for years, and the most rewarding times of that career have been when I can work my tail off to keep a donors body going long enough to harvest the organs. Donors give an amazing and precious gift to dozens people.  I've cared for both donors and recipients.  It's a beautiful and amazing thing.  Think about it and talk to your family about it.</psa>

Author: dryicerx
Content:
Just because they sell devices now, does not mean they can't or won't start selling other stuff such as services (they already provide iTunes which is more of a service). Also they used to be a Computer company which turned in to a Devices + Computer. Their just spreading their wings a bit further.

Regarding your comment about IP, I doubt they do have any kind of protection, I mean their technology is trivial at best. But the value of Twitter lies within it's user base and adoption level, that momentum is hard to beat.

I am not a big fan of Twitter or Apple, but I can definitely see a interesting potential with the two combined (imagine integrated twitter in ipod and other wireless devices). iTweet?

Author: Sam_Odio
Content:
> ... calculating the average (or arithmetic mean) of a stream's integers takes three registers and three operations per integer. One register counts the elements, another records their sum, and the third register holds the value of the average, calculated as the quotient of the sum and the count.

Here's an easy brain teaser: do the above using only two registers.

Author: andrewstuart
Title: We're looking for a graphic designer to help us win the Techcrunch50
Content:
Hi folks,
We are a startup company in stealth mode and we're working to win the Techcrunch50 (www.techcrunch50.com).  To win, we need the creative talents of a graphic designer to help us out.  It's about six weeks work, starting now.  We don't have a cash budget but we can "pay you forward" (see job ad).  It doesn't matter where you are located.  Here is the job ad http://www.seek.com.au/users/apply/index.ascx?JobID=15352696
I'm aware that finding a designer without payment is a challenge but we want to change the world and we need to be relentlessly resourceful to get there.  We'd love to hear from you.
Andrew
dukedougal@gmail.com

Author: derefr
Content:
Well, envisioning the souce of most blogging engines, the actual post source text probably goes something like this:

    blah blah blah after the jump
which is then split at the comment, and the first part shown on the main page + feeds, while the entire thing is shown on the permalinked page. Rearranging it to eliminate your quarrel would require replacing with a little SSI-like , which is a lot more complicated for not much reward.

Author: makecheck
Content:
The guy simply bought a lemon. It happens. It says absolutely nothing about the rest of the Mac line (as I've had several Macs). While I have had some frustrating experiences, they've been pretty rare; like 3 in over a decade.

When I did have serious Mac problems, it always ended up being the hardware; something easily replaced, like bad RAM. It says something when you learn to suspect hardware problems because the OS itself is so solid.
